text: Parece un cruce entre Witbier y Saison. Color amarillo pajizo, con reflejos dorados, turbio, con capa de espuma de dos dedos de grosor (retención decente). Carbonatación alta. Textura acuosa y algo efervescente. El aroma es un tanto unidimensional, con la salvia un poco más remarcada de lo que debería. También se puede captar lima, pan y algo de plátano. En boca es super refrescante y afrutada (lima, naranja), con presencia, de nuevo, del trigo (toque de pan, plátano menos presente) y final floral, herbal y especiado (mucha salvia). Menos seca de lo habitual en una Saison. Hiper refrescante postgusto a hierbas. Deliciosa.

It has a strong aroma of orange peel plus lemon and coriander. The hops dominate over the top of more traditional farmhouse flavours and theres a very warm alcohol aftertaste that lingers in the back of the throat.

This is a beer that would benefit heavily from scaling the hops back by at least half. Tropical hop notes dominate the flavor to the point where anything else struggles to get through at all. There are more complex flavors underneath those hops, but theyre faint to the point where theyre hard to identify. This has potential, but its overhopped to the point that its ruined.
Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of citrus, coriander, clove and wheat. Taste is medium sweet, lightly bitter and lightly sour.
Bottle from Voldby. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma and taste is malt, spices, fruits, floral, lots of sage. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Long finish of sage.

Golden light hazy with a frothy white head. Aromas of sage are dominant with some notes of barnyard, wheat and light funk which could all be more balanced. Light tangy, bit slick with a medium body. Briskly sweet rolling over the palate with a light acidity and light bitterness combined with a pronounced sage flavour. Medium lasting finish.

Bottle. Undated - Hazy Yellow in colour. Large foamy white head. Very herbal and grassy hops. Very spicy, sage. Yeasty. Citrus fruits. Wheaty malts. Rather earthy taste. Very herbal , citrus fruity and wheaty malty. Very dry and earthy throughout. Moderate bitterness. Nice saison witbier. (2017-03)

Aroma: perfumed fruity sweetness with sugar and slightly sour. 
Flavour: Fruity sour with hoppy bitterness and bubblegum. Aftertaste is perfumed sweetness and fruity sour. 
Colour: pale yellow with a white head.

Hazy, yellow to orange beer with a high, white, fluffy head. 
 
Nose: Grass, hay, stable, funk, caramel, citrus and vanilla. 
Taste: Yeast, floral esters, hops, citrus, grass, hay, bread and caramel malt.

Scent of grass, cloves and citrus. The taste is good and of the same. Good bitterness that fills the mouth forever. Good beer. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Bouche à lattaque ample, rétro dagrumes confits, fine bulle amère et finale sur les agrumes, grande longueur. Une blanche riche et opulente,d une grande longueur.

355ml bottle from Beer Gonzo. Pours a hazy golden yellow, large white head. Aroma is sweet yeast. Taste presents a sweet saison-like fruitiness with a pronounced hop bitterness, some floral notes.
355ml bottle. Hazy light orange shade. Short white head. Very herbal aroma with cut grass notes. Complex fruity taste, citrus peel. Interesting stuff.

Bottled. Pours slightly hazy golden with an average white head. Aroma of tangerine, grassy notes, yeast and spice. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, watery to oily texture and lively carbonation. An excellent Wheat. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

Hazy golden colour, medium white head, lacing.
Medium bite, medium sweetness, good amount of yeast and citric hops.
Medium body, creamy feel, fizzy carbonation, yeasty finish.

pours a hazy pale amber with a full head that quickly dissipates. aroma is overwhelmingly spice (white sage) with fruity esters and medicinal off-aromas. body is medium to light. carbonation is very light. there is some oil in the texture and some annoying astringency. flavor again is all about the white sage spice combined with sweet malts and the before mentioned solventy or medicinal off-flavors. there is significant bitterness still there. that bitterness and the astringency bordering on harsh lingers long after...

Many thanks to travlr for this beer! Intense fresh and slightly grainy-sourish nose. The beer starts smooth and slightly sweetish. The herbal sage is there, hints of citrus and a very smooth (but for me slightly too sweetish) body. Moderate sweetish grainy aftertaste, very soft and subtle, but neither a real farmhouse ale nor a typical witbier. For both the body is too sweetish and I miss distinctive flavours. But nevertheless a nice and easy to drink brew!

Yellow hazy with suspended particles. Rich lather that quickly disappears. Little carbonation. Clear and golden with thin head. Aroma is fairly spicy. Flavour also has some sweet spices.

355ml bottle at home in Richmond as Stillwater Cellar Door, 6.6%, undated. Very dark golden yellow, clear, lightly sparkling, foamy white head endures and leaves light lacing. Aroma is chalky, laundry powder, touch soapy, ginger, spicy, wheat, medicinal. Body is smooth, soft carbonation. Thicker white head. smells earthy unusual aroma. Taste is a little different for this style. Kinda like the basement. Carbonated see the bubbles streaming up. Pretty smooth. just a little above average. Bottle at the Winking Lizard.

Over the ages the term cellar door has numerously been referred to as the most beautiful term in the English language. Upon setting out to create the first summer addition to the Stateside line up of ales; the feeling that almost instantly came to me was that of beauty & cleansing. Many summer offerings tend to lack the complexity of their bigger, colder season counterparts; so my goal was to craft an ale of extreme balance with a delicate complexity that allows for contemplation while also providing quaffable refreshment. Starting with a base of German wheat & pale malts this crisp slightly hazy foundation was then accented with a blend of Sterling & Citra hops providing a intricate blend of herbal grass & tangerine citrus flavors and aroma. To pull this all together and to complete the cleansing aspect of my vision I gently finished the ale off with a touch of white sage, lending a mild earthy spice character to the blend. Of course lets not forget our house saison yeast that brought all the elements together leaving a dry yet intricate finish.

Pours hazy blonde with light sediment with a slight white head. Nose is tart with a little hops and citrus. Flavor is similar and richer with a nice balance of characters between a white and a saison. Finish is long and a touch funky without going too far. Better than expected.

355ml bottle. Pours a hazy yellow-orange with a huge, frothy, long lasting, white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Sweet, floral aroma of citrus, yeast, grass and sage. Sweet flavour of tangerine, floral, wheat malt, yeast, lemon, grass and sage with a dry, bitter finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Excellent witbier.

Bottle, Wine Warehouse. Pours hazy golden with very lively carbonation. Small white head. Aroma of straw, funk, random herbs. Flavor is lightly medicinal, lightly minty, with coriander, grass, and wheat. Different, but that doesnt always mean good.
Bottle. Hazy gold color. Thin white head. Taste is medium bitter. Aroma is citric, barnyard, herby, spices, mango, orange.
Pours a cloudy yellow. Aromas of citrus and spice. Flavor wasnt too Wit, White beers arent high on my list. But this one wasnt that bad, had a little more of a crisp spicy bite to it.

12 oz bottle. Hazy gold color, big fizzy white head. Aromas of straw, lemon, coriander, and honey. Light body thickened with heavy carbonation. Flavors of lemon, yeast, spices, dough, peach. Slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Nose is yeast, pepper, spice, sweet herbal note from the sage, earthy, lemon, grass. Pleasant. Taste is wheat, earthy, herbal notes, lemon, grass, sweet sage, pepper and spice with pronounced ginger in the finish. A really pleasent beer which is more Saison than Wit for me, but very enjoyable.
Pours a hazy straw from a bottle. Nice herbal aroma and flavor, definitely some nice sage. Good beer, but wish a little more going on.

Smells of lemon hey apples. A beautiful bright zesty yellow color. Tasted slightly sour some lemon with some floral notes try finish. Medium body light crisp carbonation. Quite a refreshing beer good for any time of the year. Great work.
Tap at Ginger Man, New York. Originally rated 20160212. Colour is clear orange with very small white head. Aromas and flavours: Some fruits, spices, Belgian yeast and malts. Very spicy but OK.

Gleefully blurring the line between Saison and Wheat Ale, Cellar Door borrows a bit from each style and brings loads of spice to the equation with notes of clove, white sage, and white pepper. The herbaceous influences are mellowed by citrusy, tropical tastes and a funky, fruity nose. Lately Ive been pretty thrilled with the Saisons and Sours Ive tasted that have infused savory herbs with big yeast strains. For me, Cellar Door took it to a new level. Beautifully done.

Appearance: hazy straw with one fat finger of fluffy white head diminishing rapidly to a thin skim, minimal lacing. (3/5) Aroma: dry straw, lemon zest, bready yeast, herbal, stone fruit, grassy. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, mild bitter, mild tart. (8/10) Palate: medium body, moderate-high carbonation, dry mildly bitter and tart finish. (4/5)

An interesting blend of hops and herbs give this a unique aroma. The herbs (sage) build on the tongue and gradually become more prevalent as the beer progresses, but never become unbalanced or overwhelming. I initially found it a touch too sweet, but as the bitter and spice grow in the finish, this is less and less of a problem. A very nice beer. (16/20)

Pours a hazy yellow golden color with fizzy white head. Citrus, bread, yeast, funk, and some hay on the nose; follows onto the palate. Light bodied. Finishes with wheat and some citrus.
Tap at Kool Keg. Pours a slightly hazy yellow color. Big saison elements on the nose. Barnyard, hay, dry and slightly funky. Very dry flavor and finish. A bit harsh though.
Hazy amber pour with a fluffy white head and great lacing. Aroma is citrus peel and sage. Taste follows with the sage being prevalent. Light body with soft carbonation.
Bottle from perrys liquors, livermore. Hazy deep golden color, big white head. Aroma has wheat, sour fruits, lemons, some yeasty notes. Wheat, citrus, some plums, sour notes.
Its got a lot going on -- yeast, citrus, wheat, assorted herbs -- and is perfectly drinkable but it doesnt do much for me.

Bottle at home. Aroma is spicy, perfumed, ginger, zesty citrus peel, lemon, hay, wheat, yeast, floral, pepper. Flavour is light sweet and moderate bitter. Medium bodied. Well-made and fairly complex brew, but overall a bit too spicy gingery for me to return to it.

Pretty headless,but nice body. Interesting choice of herbs. It quite works, giving a refined Belgian ale a further twist. Golden malts, enough sweetness, but perhaps not quite enough carbonation for me, for the style, to give so crispness to it. Its interesting to try but I wont go brew my own version. Beer doesnt need it. (33cl bottle from QV.ID)
pick n mix beer.it pours a hazy orangish golden medium body with a nice bubbly foam that stays for ever.the aromas are sweet,citrus.it tastes fruits , banana, and malt.rather complex i would say.

Hazy medium yellow, just shy of a finger of white head. Nose is wheat & lemon. Dry. Middle is light wheat, sage across the tongue, light malt. Finish is dry, herbal, and citrusy.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Alexei and Raphaelas. Thanks Raphaela. Hazy straw with a white ring. Citrus-orangey aroma, then rosemary and pine needles. Bitter, a little medicinal taste but mostly hoppy. Medium body, bitter, pine-like finish and medium carbonation.

12 oz bottle. 181:15. From a trade with IslandHaole. Big thanks to Dan!
Hazy yellow color with a small white head. 
Spices, wheat, yeast and more spices in the aroma. 
The flavor is yeast, hoppy bitterness, spices and wheat. 
Very strong spiciness but also rather heavy hoppiness in the flavor. 
Not as delicate I wished for but still very enjoyable.

Rated as a saison, this was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a mildly hazy burnt yellow almost orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated nicely. Lacing really spider webbed nicely.
The smell started off with some nice sweet bready malts opening up into sweet citrus and then some light earthy sweet tones. Semi-grassy sweetness with herbal qualities balancing nicely.
The taste was mainly herbally sweet with a nice light citrus to balance in the flavor. Breadiness clings in the aftertaste with a running sweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a semi-sweet stickiness rolling over my tongue. Fairly sessionable for the most part.
Overall, Id say this was a nice sweet bready saison. Id have again.

Bottle from Rudat in Dortmund. The beer has got a hazy light golden colour with an airy head and medium body. Aroma of wheat, yeast and flowers, Taste of wheat, grains, herbs and flowers. Citric hints.

Pours gold with a small head.
Nose shows lemon, musk sticks, bergamot, confectionery notes, soft peppery phenols.
Flavours include more of the herbal characters, some soft acidity, a bit of sweet doughy wheat notes.

Bottle (bb?) kindly shared by bastarda, danke! - Earthy aromas of dank coriander, old lemongrass, lavendar (suppose white sage) cue traits reminding me of the heavier-than-usual wit Blanche Double style (cf. Abbaye des Rocs Blanche des Honnelles), not a personal favourite. Dryish, attenuated "farmhouse"-style mouthfeel meets almond in taste, on top of spicier notes of lemongrass, whiskyish malts and lime peel, hurtling towards a vegetal-herbal (sage) and hopbitter finish. A bit of everything here.

nose: white sage, and white sage. Taste: quite monodimensional, but nicely balanced. A lot of white sage again, nice mouthfeel. A taylor-made sage bitter ending; surprising Golden Delicious aftertaste, nice in this beer.

Nose is sweet citrus, dried apricot, sage/floral. Flavor opens with lemony citrus acidity, transitions into clovey spice, herbaceous/planty, stone fruit, and mango, finish is mild grapefruit and off dry.

Pours a cloudy medium-golden color with a huge, well-retaining, off white head. Lemony and very lightly earthy nose. Moderately crisp on the palate. Mouthfeel is precisely like the nose except that the lemon expresses more and like a shandy.
Smells of citrus and wet dough. Beautiful glowing orange with very quickly dissipating head. Smooth warming herbal sage over a medium wheat body. Well balanced.

355ml bottle. Hazed gold pout. Aroma is tart, herbal, and citrus. Flavor is herbal, some grassiness, bitterness, pretty dry. This is abrasive stuff. Not what im lookign for in the style. Rubbery finish.
12 oz bottle pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of grains, citrus and sage. Taste is spicy yeast, sage and lemon.

On tap at Falling Rock Tap House in downtown Denver. An 8 ounce pour in a stemmed bulbous glass. A somewhat cloudy yellow amber beer with moderate white head and a pronounced sour fruity nose. Yassir! Big and complex fruits on hand here. Reminiscent of dried and candied peaches, apricots. Incredible! 4.

I must have liked it in 2013, but I dont recall much right now. I dont even recall if it was tap or bottle. Complete fail on my part.

Draft. Pours a hazy golden orangish color. Aroma and taste are spiced, lemon, and floral.
Tap. Cloudy orange-yellow . Thin white head. Floral notes dominate the aroma. Herbal. Very dry with a bit of rosemary, herb and flowers. Lots of bitter hops for a long finish. I love this beer.

Well first of all, the bottle says its a farmhouse ale, so negative points for calling it something its not. Otherwise, it reeks of coriander and awful spices you find in your grandmothers kitchen, and a little bit of french fry aroma. Its got weird spicy, garden flavors and it all over the top and fake.

May 9, 2015. Bottle at home. 
Clear golden with a medium sized white head. Aroma is herbal and earthy with sage, rosemary, pine, coriander, juniper and citrus on top of sweet floral honey. Taste is medium sweet floral with a light bitterness. Finish is light bitter with sage and rosemary, sweet floral honey notes. Light to medium bodied, average, small bubble carbonation.

Golden sparkling pour with white head. Strong funky aroma with sour notes. The flavour is unique, the sourness reminds of what youd find in a cheese, there are earthy notes, the mouthfeel coats your tongue somewhat. Complex, some herbal flavours from the sage, very very nice.

On tap at Mission Dolores. Slight hazy pale orange white creamy head. Aroma is lemon peel, clove, slight banana, bubblegum, traditional Belgian spices. Flavor is lemon, wheat, coriander, slight Christmas spices, nutmeg. Not bad.

Pleasant saison aroma which a more floral touch than the average saison. Very slightly citrusy too. Taste is more sweet than the saison Im used to drink but still its a quite dry and very crisp beer. Its a very well realized beer with nice fruitiness, perfectly coupled with maltiness. Mouthfeel is just perfect, not watery at all and that works awesome with the style. Quite high carbonation too. Again, each sip reminds me how perfectly its made. That could be a modern version of the Saison Dupont without any doubt.
Bottle. Pours a clear gold with little head. Spicy lemongrass aroma. Spicy, fruity and light. A very fun flavour.

On tap @Ma che siete venuti a fà (Rome). Pours cloudy yellow with a little head. Aroma is spiced, with citrus notes, malt, more similar to a saison. Flavour is rich and complex, just a bit messy, malt, grain, fruits, yeasts. Mmedium body, good carbonation. Nice beer, it could be a world class if it was a little more refined.

355ml bottle from Tanakaya. Poured into a Duvel tulip glass. Slightly hazy golden color with a modest amount of foam that dissipates fairly quickly. Big fruit aromas up front: papaya, passion fruit, citrus along with hints of corriander, cinnamon and barnyard/brett. As it warms up the brett and barnyard flavors take over in a good way. Medium body with a slightly oily texture. Lively carbonation and a nice finish that is mostly bitter with a hint of sourness. Its like a saison and witbier all wrapped up together.
12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy melon orange. No head. Aroma is grainy, grassy, sweet, bitter, and herbal. Really delicious stuff.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy straw color with a thick white head and lots of bubbles. Citrus aroma. Citrus comes through in the flavor with a nice balance of malt and hop. Really carbonated though which is distracting. Pretty light and refreshing. Not my favorite style but Id drink this one again.

Bottle pour into Goblet. Aroma has hay and herbs with an indistinct citrus overlay. Appearance is bright amber, golden with a decent white head, slight lacing that doesnt linger. Taste is lightly bitter, with a hint of sweetness and lasting grapefruit flavor. Texture is thin and carbonation is visible and fizzy. Finish is astringent and dry. Would be an enjoyable summer beer, alas it is still winter here. This is a pretty solid farmhouse but a bit rough around the edges.
Fluffy white head, 3 fingers in depth. Translucent and pale straw yellow in color. Aroma is citrus and sage. Taste of sage is overpowering and it has a weird aftertaste. Really not liking this one.
nice brew from Stillwater. Aroma of saison, resin. floral, leaves, some alcohol, grassy, citrus
Very nice saison. Smooth and tasty. A little pricey, but will buy again. Faint citrus and spice

Poured from bottle into teku glass. Pours honey yellow and translucent with a sparse white foam head. 

The nose shows mostly honey, herbs, and some slight hints of citrus fruits with the distinct barnyard/farmhouse aroma. 

The palate is medium bodied. The first impressions shows mostly spices and herbs along with the bitterness that follows for some of those herbs (not from the hops). The farmyard flavor tends play a role in the background of these spices. The finish shows very faint hints of malts but the mid-palate shows a spiciness that tends to last too long afterwards. Not many fruit flavors just a lot of the spices and herbs that take center stage making it somewhat difficult to approach.

A big surprise. Poured a golden yellow with a white laced head. Smooth and full bodied taste with the slight earthy taste if safe complementing the floral and grass hops. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Lovely subtle and intricate flavours of citrus, herbal, slight banana, and Stillwaters saison yeast. Would rate this a lot higher if it wasnt for the over-pronounced sweetness. Its not a cloying sweetness but is mainly evident on the midpalate. Ive found a few of Stillwaters saisons are just slightly too sugary and overbearing in comparison to the other delicate flavours in the beers. I guess the head brewer has a sweet tooth!

From notes. Tasted on 10/21/12 from a capped 750mL bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a thick white head that slowly recedes to fairly thick, even lace. The nose is straightforward wit with light malt and plenty of spice. The flavor is quite spicy, not much malt, a solid example of the style, but not terribly interesting. The body is light with overactive carbonation and a medium spiced finish.

New Years Eve tasting Flight (1 of 3 7:14p) - bottled. Serious amounts of carbonation! Apricot color with a large head to float a dime on. Aroma of peach and tangerine orange. Feel the carbonation on the palate. Nice bitterness, and dryness from the time on the sage. Bitterness lingers on the palate after a minute, or two.

Orange, super hazy, frothy white head. Smell of belgian yeast esters, fruity malts, some hops and spices. Moderate sweet, quite fruity, nice malt flavors, melon, quite nice. Moderate bitter finish. Very nice belgian. Lovely and complex

Pours a sediment-filled golden with a resilient white head. Aroma is...grains. Flavor is fruity, lemon, orange, light spices. Finish is herbal and citrusy. Lingering lemon-lime. Extremely refreshing. Medium body, average to strong carbonation.

Aroma: citrus, some wild notes, wheat, spices
Taste: medium bitter, low sour, spicy, citrus, some alcohol
Julie did not have.  The sage makes it taste like a belgium ale in stead of an American farm house ale

Bottle at the beer bistro.
Hazy golden pour, with a huge white head. Big earthy aroma, im gettin the sage, and some notes of lavender. Big hops, zesty citrus, some yeasty notes, with a nice corriander finish. Quite complex, mouth feel is a big fuller than i expected, but this was super satusfying, and refeshing. Finish was a touch dry, with some herbs, and more of the earthy herbs, and citrus zest.

De fines bulles très actives narrivent pas à se cacher totalement dans une marée dorée assez trouble qui se laisse caresser par une mousse blanche généreuse. Des esters fruités et puissants de mangues et de bananes, notamment, sont rehaussés par un aspect floral assez poignant, gracieuseté de la sauge blanche. Au fil des respirations, il y a même une petite pointe mentholée qui est apparue. Les saveurs florales se retrouvent également en bouche dans une effervescence assez vive. Les céréales sont croustillantes et épicées, et se marient bien avec la levure aux phénols intenses. Une jolie sécheresse en finale nous donne envie de reprendre une autre gorgée rapidement. Petit bémol par contre, le houblonnage était presque complètement disparu, étant donné que ma bouteille datait de 5-6 mois, mais nempêche que cétait une bière complexe et intéressante à déguster.
I had this a while back but havent rated. From memory its pretty good but nothing really stands out.

Very unclear pale yellow color with a big fine white head. Nice lacing down the glass. Nice unusual aroma. Yeast, mild citric, spruce, some spices and wheat. Fine body. Ok balance between sweetness and bitterness. High carbonation. Still very pleasant to drink although the high carbonation. Citric, fruity, some spices, spruce and some yeast. Nice tasty ale.[Bottle at SOT Bar & Burger in Trondheim, Norway]
On draft at Isaac Newtons. Notes of banana, clove, spice, wheat and citrus. A nice earthy and citrus finish. A nice wit.

Bottle from Erzbierschof - Hazy pale yellow color with a huge creamy white head, long lasting, beautiful lacing - Aroma is yeasty, spicy, citrusy, orange peal, wheat, sage - Flavor is citrusy, herbal, wheat, spicy - Light/medium body, medium bitterness, medium carbonation, smooth and bitter, medium sage bitter finish - Delicious beer, refreshing and tasty, lake of carbonation
Bottle from Cotteridge wines. Golden beer with large head, lively. Aroma is some banana and yeast. Taste is tangerine, yeast, spices and citrus with a little grapefruit. Decent.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from Cellarbrations Sandy Point February 2014. Packed full of fruit aromas and flavours, peach, nectarine and melon. Slight maltiness and a strong finish.

Pours a finger of head on a slightly hazy light straw colored body.
The aroma has a lot of fresh ground black pepper, a little sage and earth.
The taste is peppery, mild grain and lemon bitterness. 
The texture is soft and fizzy.
An improvement on the standard wit beer.

Foggy, oaky gold. Big, fluffy, stiff head. Cool label. Standard longneck. Almost savory, light vinegar, some stewed fruit, phenols. Fermented apricot, black pepper, bandaid, yeasty. Lightish body, effervescent. Tangy aftertaste, sticky chemical aftertaste. Saison is, at best, sufferable. Beer Stop.
I really liked this; light and fruity with more of a saison flavor than a Belgian wit but bubbly and refreshing. Really good.

""touch" of white sage my butt! that was the dominating factor in the aroma and flavor. quite pleasant, but a surprisingly one-trick pony. on tap, so i was saved from another gusher. nice medium-full mouthfeel, even with the prickly carbonation. a little yeast and sweetness in the background, but this beer showcased the sage without being as funky or saison-like as the other Stillwater brews Ive had. 7/12 - hops (good) + carbonation (bad) come through more in the bottle. More complex in aroma and flavor, but the feel suffers, too gassy."

bottle @ Vino Bellissimo / Lima OH --- Nice aroma of sage and citrus. Nearly clear medium amber with a solid 1/2" white head, streaky lace. Good looking. Taste is unique and cleansing - wheat and malt are present, but so are herbs and earthy, dry-grass sage. It all moves smoothly to a lingering finish that is mostly earth and dry-grass bittering that is somehow appealing. It isnt exactly a Witbier, but it is original, and it is very good.

large white frothy head. good lacing. mostly diminishing. dark yellow thick hazy body. aroma: moderate hoppy, citrur orange, coriander, sage. if: moderate sweet (honey, fruity). ff: light sweet acidic and bitter, plus salty; long duration. palate: light medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation and light astringent finish. bem condimentada (lembra manjericão, sálvia e coentro). bem diferenciada do estilo, com alguma acidez de limão, mas com ligeiro amargor e bem mais temperada. sente-se um pouco de álcool no final. uma das mais complexas representantes do estilo já degustadas por mim. 130s
Tap at CBC 2014. Beer in the glass deep golden, small head. Mild fruity aroma. Starts malty, spicy, notes of some herbs, mild sweetish. Finish more dry, a bit yeasty. Fruity like peach. Okay.

Appearance: lightly hazed medium gold; short creamy white head.  Aroma: lightly herbal, with light lemongrass and citrus.  Taste: 	funky, slightly salty, with strong notes of sage. Finish: sour fruit, light smoke. Notes: Didnt much work for me, although it got better as it warmed a bit. On draft at Quench! in Silver Spring, Maryland

Well, certainly has one of the nicest names to say of any beer. Bottled 05/06/14. Nose is heavy wheat, heavy spice (sage, dominant, probably too much), light citrus peel and juice, lemon, orange, tangerine. Pours lightly hazy but boldly intense golden with above avg carb and a rocky-soapy white head. Taste is lightly tart and lightly bittern, sweet but not cloying (its probably secondary sweetness that does it), strong scratchy spice with strong citrus (orange and tangerine) in good balance with each other. Yeast is highly peppery. Fullish body, spice and wheat dominate the finish and aftertaste, probably too heavy for me to consider refreshing, but clean and crisp and a worth experiment in moving the Wit away from tradition.
Bottle at Brewdog Edinburgh. Pours cloudy pale amber, nose is estery, spices, herbal, taste is dry, toffee, light citrus, fruity.
Acid aroma. Balanced. Wheat and a little bit of fruity taste. Spicy. Medium carbonation and medium body. Slightly bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 4 oz draft pour at ChurchKey on 8/4/2014. Clear light golden yellow with off-white head. Aromas of herbs, floral notes, spices. Tastes of herbs, floral notes, spices, stone fruit, apples. Medium body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation. 7/4/7/4/14

4 oz pour on draft at B Side on 2/17/2015. Clear orange with off-white head. Aromas of herbs, floral, citrus. Tastes of lemon and orange citrus, herbs, floral, black peppery notes. Medium body with a dry finish. 7/4/8/4/16
Tap. Clear orange yellow pour. White pepper, citrus, fruit, juice. Spicy carbonation, sweet fruity body. Light to medium body. Nice

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2014 Keg at the Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2014, yellow session. 02/05/2014. pale golden coloured pour with a thin fleeting white head. Aroma is wit yeast esters, orange, light straw earthyness. Flavour is crisp, yeasty, straw and grainy malts. Some orange fruits lingers. Didn;t get much sage. Palate is wheat, moderately high carbonation.

Opaque/cloudy yellow orange colour with a white head. Aroma is strong orange and citrus notes. Taste is effervescent on the tongue. Hints of coriander and orange in the taste.

Gold pour, small white head. Aroma is citrus, earth, spices and yeast. Flavor is orange peel, yeast, herbs. Crisp and refreshing. Delicious.

Orange pour with white head. Aroma is candy and sweet citrus. Taste follows nose. Little funk. Lots is sweet and carbonation. Nice.

Deep golden pour with white head. Nose of meaty citrus, yeast, and candy. Flavor is bright lemon citrus with lightly sweet candy, before fading quickly to bitter citrus rind and mild herbal hops. Finishes dry with ample carbonation. Really nice.

Bottle pour. Pours light golden with a nice Belgian like aroma. Solid Belgian white ale. Really nice spicy citrus flavors. Orange spice finish, but mild overall. Good beer.

Bottle from Vika enjoyed at home
Orange, super hazy, frothy white head. Smell of belgian yeast esters, fruity malts, some hops and spices. Moderate sweet, quite fruity, nice malt flavors, melon, quite nice. Moderate bitter finish. Very nice belgian. Lovely and complex

The quaint, bucolic origin story of the French farm saison I know, but the lore (or myth) behind the idea of an American farmhouse ale is something alien to me, even with my American citizenship. Still, wherever this beer come from, and however it was inspired, this is a wonderfully dry beverage for summer drinking. Much more exotic indeed, its not an IPA. The heavy, wet straw color hints at a rich cornucopia of grains, with a thin fizzy headed that quickly floats away, and a haziness that comes partly from a cold serving temperature. White grapes, straw and basil compose a sophisticated, dry aroma, with other botanical touches including fennel seed. And the taste is a suitable match. Theres much less white grape flavor here until somewhere near the aftertaste. Instead, the palate is focused on a wonderfully balanced blend of wheat notes, a touch of dry lemon peel or even lemon verbena, some lemon grass, more thyme, and even a touch of white pepper in the finish. As always, these styles of beers are hard for me to wrap my ahead around, but I like them. The better that medley of tastes and grains - the closer to some idealized aroma of a fresh harvest - the more enjoyable these brews get, and this counts high among their number.

Bottle. Light golden body with a frothy white head. Aroma of juniper, toasted grain, hibiscus, spice, leafy hops, herbs, coriander, sage. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Way too much going on in this beer in the flavor, especially with the spices, that arent working together. Drinkable but not especially enjoyable. The aroma was nice and the barrel-aged version a lot nicer.

12 oz. on tap. Hazy golden with a lasting head. Spicy toffee, resin, light funky grape must on the nose. Tastes of the same good stuff plus some light citrus zest and earthy spice. Medium body has a nice balance and a medium-high but smooth carbonation.
Bit of a citrus grapefruit aroma, has a nice citrus kick, tingly body, bit of wheat. Not the worst
12 ounce bottle from Tullys in Wells, Maine, fruity aroma, grape flavor, fairly sweet.

Bottle from Hazels beverage world. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with hops, citrus, wheat, earthy notes, spices and tropical fruits. Bitter finish with hops, citrus and earthy notes. Excellent belgian white.

Bona cervesa, té un petit toc a pebre que és molt característic.
Buena cerveza, tiene un pequeño toque a pimienta que es muy característico.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Nose is a hopped up farmhouse with plenty of lychee, grass and bubblegum. Taste is mango, lychee, bubblegum and moderate straw. Very clean and moderately sweet. Drinks well. Nice

Pours a cloudy light golden, with a fine white head. Nose is yeasty, slighty barnyardy, grass, I get some of the citrus in citra, banana, slightly spicy. Flavor is banana, spice, yeasty, a little orange, with a dry and spicy finish. Really great. My description doesnt do it justice, but the flavors in this are really cohesive, and more complex than Im describing. Not only that, but its more of a continuum of flavors, because theyre just blended so well. Standard carbonation with a medium body. Really excellent.

Small coarseish white head. Hazy yellow body. Spicy orangey
white sage aroma with mealy herbal notes. Dryish spicy orangey
white sage taste with mealy herbal notes. So basically, taste is
identical to aroma. Mid-bodied. Mild, mealy, flattish
mouthfeel. Dryish mealy wooden white sage aftertaste with spicy
fruity notes. Nice, drinkable, unusual and really showcases the
white sage (which is really recognizable from Nøgne Øs Special
Holiday Ale), but perhaps a bit flat and lacking in
complexity. (0.355l bottle, from wine monopoly, Vika, Oslo.)

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a small head. Aroma is nice peppery yeast with lots of fruity peaches, as well as roasted malts and kandi. Medium body with soft carbonation. Flavour is tart with earthy yeast, kandi and some spices. Nice lingering yeast in the finish.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 12 oz bottle- Pours a very hazy straw golden with a one finger white head that reduces to a blanket. Aroma is lemony, perfumy, sage and thyme. The taste is lemony, a little funk, sage and other spices, creamy. I had Stone saison just before this, (although they are different styles the spices and taste made them very similar in my opinion) I hate to admit that i was a little disappointed in that beer, and was assuming this one was going to be a masterpiece compared, instead this does have the edge, but was a little disappointed in this one as well. Very nice beer, I just wish they would cut back on the spices a bit.

On tap at Saint John. Golden blonde with a white head. Peppery, floral, citrusy, and a little wheat in the aroma. Taste is sweet initially with yeast and citrus, straw, leading to a spicy dry finish. Lovely.

Stillwater Cellar Door has a thick, spongy, white head, incredible lacing, and a fiercely bubbly, orange-gold, opaque appearance, with visible little brown specs settling at the bottom. Uma festa de aromas e sabores! 
Imagine a combinação de uma witbier bem condimentada com uma saison destacando as leveduras belgas. É ela.

Small festival glass, draught at Copenhagen Beer Celebration, first session. Clear golden. Low white head. Citrus, semi-dry, aroma. Herbal hops and lemon to the taste character added by a smooth touch of ginger. Drying fruit finish. Fine balanced. Easy to drink, thirst quencher. (02.05.2014).

Warner Robins, Ga. - Lazy Dog Growler - 12 oz bottle. Slightly hazy medium golden with a sticky snow white head that leaves a nice coat of lacing. Aroma has some nice coriander notes, a touch of yeast and a hint of clove. Flavor is robust with nice clove undertones, a touch of coriander and just a hint of banana fruitiness. Nice sticky, thick mouthfeel with just the right amount of spritz. Another solid entrant from Stillwater.
Tap at Le Garage. Spicy and herbal flowery base. Fullbodied dry body. Perfumed finished.
Tap at the Copenhagen beer festival.... Golden amber... Soft white head... Soft floral lifht salty nose... Soft fruits.. Juicy orange... Big salty. Linger

Really fresh, original and enticing aroma. Mint, herbal, toothpaste some lemon zest, citrus, floral notes and wet grass. A little lemonade influence, lager-shandy esque.

Taste is even more perplexing. Lemon, yeast, ginger. Sage offers a herbal, earthy instigator. Palate very dry and theres a glorius light spicy rising bitterness on the back-end. Ginger lingers on the palate.

The beer looks and feels like a cleansing tool - due to its slick presentation and clean mouth-feel. A nice refreshing brew.

Tap at Fermentoren, Copenhagen. Poured a hazy straw colour with a thin white head and some broken lace. The aroma is yeast, citrus, floral hop. The flavour is medium to light bitter with a citrus floral light spice, toothpaste mint palate and a short bitter finish. Medium to light bodied with average carbonation. Lots going on and super refreshing.

This was at esbls Poured in my tasting glass a cloudy gold color. Nice off=white head and good lacing. The nose is soft stone fruit. Medium in body. Flavor is is strong of the fruit and lots of spice. Very tasty.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 12/5/2013. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy bright gold color with a 2 finger fairly dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big lemon zest, tangerine, orange peel, pear, apple, pepper, sage, herbal, floral, grass, wheat, cracker, light bubblegum, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus hops, yeast ester, and spice notes; with great strength. Taste of big lemon zest, tangerine, orange peel, pear, apple, pepper, sage, grass, herbal, floral, wheat, cracker, light bubblegum, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of earthy spice/bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon zest, tangerine, orange peel, pear, apple, pepper, sage, grass, herbal, wheat, cracker, light bubblegum and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic complexity and balance of hop, yeast ester, and spice flavors; with a great yeast/spice flavor balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome spiced saison style. All around great complexity and balance of hops, yeast ester, and spice flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

A subtle and bold version of a Belgian wit. Lots of head, it really had the perfect amount of fizz and bubbles. The description is accurate, the pale malts, citrus, wheat, hops and earthiness are all elements that almost seem like a saison, or an APA. Finish is dry, bitter, mild carbonation.
Draught.Hazy yellow colour with large White head.Aroma of yeast and spices,even taste of bananas,good lively mouthfeels and strong spicy flavor well balanced and fresh finish.

Draft at Of Love & Regret. Pours cloudy dark gold with a bubbly white head. Tastes like herbs, lavender, light yeast, light soapyness. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like yeast, crackers, light creaminess, light herbs.

On tap at the Stillwater at Dig Bar. Saison. It pours a clear deep gold with a thin filmy head that quickly dissipates. A huge sage aroma assaults your nose in a good way. The flavor is somewhat candy sweet with a funky saison character and tons of sage. Really interesting stuff.
bottle. Golden with one finger head. Light body with light, crisp hops and an awesome spicing, including sage and citrus.

It pours a hazy orange yellow with a fine 1" layer of foam. It smells spicy, of citrus hops with a strongish aroma of lemon zest.

Lemon grass and I guess, that Sage are giving me big time citrusy bitterness and an earthy "feel" that I think is quite unusual but very tasty. It ends on the decidedly dry and still very bitter side. Yummy. Medium bodied with perhaps a tad too much carbonation but thats a minor quibble.

This surprised me, though the ratings are on the good to very good side on average. The surprising thing? Today is April 5, 2014. This bottle has a bottling date of April 23, 2013. Wow, that is nothing short of amazing!

Clear golden body, medium to thin white head, sparse lacing. Sage is undeniable as it hits you immediately after the cap is removed. Light citrus and peppery yeast follows. Medium to light bodied, lively carbonation, dry, yeasty finish.

On draught at Pdx farmhouse and wild ale fest - pours clear golden with small head. Nose of safe, grass, and herbs. Taste of bitter sage, grass, and pine.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Golden pour with decent white head. Nose is yeast, bananas, and citrus. Taste follows the nose with some mild barnyard funk. Pretty good.

Cloudy light golden color with amazing thick white foamy head. Spicy, yeasty, herbal aroma. Malty, peppery, earth, citrus flavor with some yeast and sage flavors. Bitter grapefruit zest finish . Bubbly feel in mouth. Really nice well crafted brew. This is my first Stillwater Artisanal and I cant wait to try more.

Pours a golden orange with a paper thin white head. Aroma of wheat, chamomile, spices and citrus. Taste is herbal, ginger, bitter citrus and wheat. Not bad, like a saison/wit hybrid

355ml bottle. Pours light gold with a small head. Aroma is herbal with coriander. Grassy with a touch of Citra. Taste is wheaty to start with a little lime in the finish and Wine Gums on the aftertaste.
bottle from dbarnold. pours hazy light gold, thin white head. nose is herbal. taste has balance, lightly floral, bubblegum. light body.

Medium-high strength of aroma and very nicely lingering.Malt and sage collide and are wedded perfectly, up front. It gives a wonderfully rustic character and while the rest of the beer is very cleanly and elegantly done, it gives it its own distinct charm. Medium bodied, with a soft texture from the wheat and engaging, tight carbonation. Absolutely LOVE the maltiness. I drank this much faster than Ive drank most dry session ales lately, unintentionally. It just works that well. Its good to see an American brewer that can do a sweeter, spiced Belgian ale. Not too many can.

The beer pours a golden orange color, like a deep, dark piss. The beer forms a light head of pale white bubbles that quickly fizzle away to a thin, almost-non-existent scrim on the sides of the glass. In body, the beer is clean but murky, with just faint suggestions light and shapes coming through from the other side of the glass. Upon further examination, tiny specs can be seen floating in the beer, though none are of a considerable size. On the nose, the beer smells smoothly funky with saison yeast and a good touch of pepper that spices the nose. Pineapple and a touch of orange juice can also be sensed on the nose, along with a nice, light wheat flake scent that suggests the beers malt. The pineapple smell blends in and out of the funk smell, suggesting a presence of juicier hops and some nice, hay-like funk. On the tongue, the beer tastes fruity sweet and acidic with a light, tart pucker to the mouth and a very light touch of bitterness, which comes through more in the aftertaste. In flavor, the beer begins as light wheat malt, immediately exploding into huge pineapple bursts of flavor with herbal, funky side flavors and a light bitter grapefruit. The funk is deep enough that I think I detect some brett in the flavor, though I didnt think this beer had any in it The finish is dry, yet full of pineapple funk flavors and just a touch of wheat malt, which the aftertaste accentuates. In the mouth, the beer feels sharp in carbonation, coming in somewhere on the heavy side of medium, while the body sits on the tongue comfortably at a medium weight. The mouth is left dry except for acid cancelling saliva on the sides of the cheeks and a light stickiness on the tongue. Overall, this is a nice little saison with some rich complexity. It is delicate and very fruity with its funk, most likely due to the addition of white sage. Its not my favorite American Farmhouse Ale though. Its good and tasty and I would never turn it down, but it doesnt seem like the type of beer I would drink more than one of at a sitting, as it sits in the stomach a little heavy. Its rich and complex, but it doesnt light up my palate like it has for others.

S: This is very sage-forward. Buried underneath that note is a solid undercurrent of orange peel. I wouldnt really consider it complex, but it sure is evocative the way the aroma balances itself between these two notes.

T: The opening flavors are quite spicy, with additional notes of coriander to go along with all of that white sage. Further sips help to accentuate a wonderful tone of orange peel, also. Theres also a bit more complexity than the aroma suggested (subtle notes of apricot, cream, and wheat show up). This brew is really about the excellent sage and citrus peel character, however.

M: Initial heftiness is a tad much, however the finish helps to alleviate this with its crisp, clean finish. Carbonation is high, par for the style.

O: Subjectively, saisons are pretty hit-and-miss for me. Id easily call this a hit though, thanks to its balance between drinkability and good (but not great) complexity.

Medium-bodied, with a spicy, tingly mouthfeel. Very dry finish. This was a big letdown after the last Stillwater I drank. For the money I could get a much better brew. I think the combo of spices turns me off.  Meh.

Hazy orange golden layered color/ off white head. Citrusy tart wheat, lemongrass, tangerine, pale malt aromas. Light frothy mouthfeel. Nice citrus orange, lemongrass, tart wheat, herbal mint, dry spice flavors--very good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: bright golden pour with a big fluffy whity head. Nose is citrus and floral with grassy notes. Light bodied. Citrus and floral hops, Moderate spiced (sage?) along with the wheat pepperiness.  Nice summer sasion. dryish finish.  almost too much spice but a  solid effort

sample at Dr. Bills GABF Tasting at Falling Rock on 10/1/11.  cloudy yellow pour with a 2 finger white head.  coriander and spice nose.  medium body with more citrus notes and a light bitterness.  smooth.  dry finish.

Had this on cask. Poured hazy orange with no head. Smelled of hops, mainly citrus and it had some herbal notes. Tasted surprisingly bitter and the herbal component shined through. This would probably impressed me more cold.

Comes out of the bottle a slightly hazy, pretty solar yellow with a nice thick white head. Malty aroma has a decided overtone of sage - oh yes, you can smell that, and it makes this beer all the more appealing! OK, on to tasting - yummy! Malty, fruity, earthy, with that sage overtone that makes it distinctive. Notes of banana and pear enhance the sweetness without making it too sweet. I do not like beer that is over-sweet! Body is about average, but it is fairly fizzy and leaves a nice malty finish with an overtone of that sage. Get it whilst thou canst!
@ ACBF 2011. The aroma is spicy en veggie. Hazy, yellow coloured beer with a white head. The taste is light bitter, bit sweet, has some citric sourness, malts, spice. Interesting.

Poured from a 750 ml into a tulip.  Pours a nice golden color with a big pillowy head.  Aroma is primarily grassy and floral with hints of orange and some other citrus, decent smelling.  The floral hops come to the front in the taste, supported by grassy and orangey notes.  This one is relatively light and crisp and pretty refreshing.  A little overcarbonated, which detracts from the floral and citrus in the taste.  Overall, a drinkable and refreshing beer, but not outstanding.

Bomber. Ginger and spice nose, warm wheat. Very spicy, interesting, sage, too much herbs. Orange and cloudy with lace. Big, sweet, fruity and herbal flavor with sage, herbal bitterness, also a tart edge and a bit of banana. Nice fruit. Finish is a bit dull. Interesting.

750ml bottle from ksurkin. Pours a hazy orange with a thick, foamy, long lasting, white head. Aroma of spicy yeast, oranges, herbal tea and honey. Flavor of sweet honey malt, tart Belgian yeast and a zesty citrus bitterness. Light body with lively carbonation and a frothy mouth feel. This is a nice, easy drinking beer, the spices are a bit strong for my palate but it is still enjoyable.

750 ml bottle from michael-pollack- thanks again, Pollack! Pours a hazy, deep golden color with a big, fizzy eggshell white head that settles quickly into a lasting thin cap. A little foam came out of the cap upon opening, but not a gusher. Aroma of basement funk, sage, spice, floral hops, hay, white bread, tropical fruits, and candi sugar. Flavor of sage, spices, pepper, pale malts, tropical fruits, wheat, crackers, and straw. Medium-bodied, with a spicy, bubbly mouthfeel and high carbonation. Not an easy drinker- a little harsh on the palate- and I generally like a wit that I can savor a little longer. But otherwise a really nice wit.

Geruch süßlich, kräuterig und gewürzig nach Salbei, etwas hefig. Süßlich-gewürzter Start. Mitte herber, erinnert an Cassis mit Salbeieinflüssen. Herb-trocken und leicht säuerlich abschließend. Gut - ziemlich abgefahren.

It doesnt get much more earthy than this. This brewer has balls and imagination. I can think of so many places, situations and pairings where this beer would be magnificent. Its really a crime to drink this beer alone and not paired with anything. The sage is brilliant. Gourmet. I would like a little richer body. Truly artistic.

Wit? - more like a saison - hugely carbonated, fizzy pour - hazy golden - dry aroma and dusty yeast, strong sage, toasted wheat, wildflowers, mild phenols - dry up front, with strong wheat, moderate phenols - a little sweet on the tail end - sage, peppery character, orange and other citrus - cobweb - chewy yeast - good, but a bit too sweet on the end for my taste.

Bottle thanks to Brandon, slightly over gushed but nice slightly hazy orange yellow pour with white head, aroma has lots of sage, grass, tangerine, pear, lots of apricot.  Really nice and fruity.  Taste is nice sage, some pine, grass, touch of tangerine, apricot, some nice yeasty notes, touch of biscuit, with a slightly sweet finish.  Would be nice to be a bit drier, but overall tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Bottle courtesy of Brandon. Thanks! Cloudy orange appearance with a big, fluffy white head. Floral, citrusy, slightly spicy, slightly yeasty, wheat malty nose. Floral, herby, slightly spicy, light wheat malty, a touch tart flavor. Pretty tasty, interesting beer.

Bomber.

Very glad that the guys have hit Washington state. Distinctive house yeast recalls the Stateside Saison; sage is forward in what is a rich and hearty rather than light and refreshing witbier.

Bottle at Patricks, shared by gunnfryd. Pours a hazy straw yellow with decent white head. Aroma is citrus, earth. Taste is very slightly sour, light sweet, light bitter. Light to medium body, thin, lively carbonation. 20110602

750 ml bottle poured a clear gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, sage and light citrus. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of wheat, sage,light citrus and light straw with a crisp lingering sage finish.

A hazed golden wit with a thin white head. In aroma, nice fruity esters, peaches, light lactic and creamu notes. In mouth, a smooth saison like offering, fruity , chalky noes, medium bodied. On tap at Delirium Café Hoppy Loft, July 13 2011.

Pours a cloudy, light yellow with a froth white head. Aroma is intensely herbal with a slight spice working in the background. Nice effervescent and a decent body. The citrus flavor is very slight and unusual for a white. Expect a little more of that in this style but I actually prefer the muted aspect better. The finish is a touch bitter on the back of the palate. Nice body and malt profile.  Pretty enjoyable summer drink.

Draught at Hoppy Loft, Brussels. Pours a very cloudy yellow with a small diminishing white head. Nice aroma, sweet, with light hops first followed by yeast, herbs, grain and some spices. Flavour of citrus fruit, hops, herbs, spices and a decent bitter tart finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good, enjoyable.

DØE Festival, Valby, DK.
Tap, 270511.
Yellow with white head. Aroma of wheat and spices. Flavor with some citrus and more wheat.

bottle poured a nice golden in color with steady streaming carbonation and a cap of white head. aroma has sage, dusty yeast, pepper, and some grassy flowers. mouth feel is light and there is high side carbonation. flavor gets a bit barnyard, pepper, sage, hop pokes, fairly dry, and finishes with flowers and grass. nice and snappy but not too heavy on the herbs and it kept me interested the whole glass.
Draught from rattle.  Orange yellow cloudy pour. Very citrusy aroma - orange and grapefruit.  Bitter taste. Some yeast.

Aroma of herbal bread from the neck. Notes of lemon zest, alcohol, herbs. Higly carbonated, giant mousse head, and flavors of sage, pepper, and citrus in the middle. Very dry, lightly bittered finish. Floral & soapy aromas from the glass. Tasted from the 750ml @ 62F.

Dry hay in color with a towering ivory head.  Aroma of lemon grass, yeast, and mild citrus.  Flavor is crisp and clean with some fresh cracked pepper, light barnyard, and citrus.  Medium mouthfeel.  Really nice.

750 mL bottle. Pours a clear, pale yellow color with a thick white head and no lacing. The aroma is lemons, green apples, hay, and a lot of yeasty funk. The flavor is fruity sweetness up front and through the middle, with a little bitterness and sourness in the finish. The palate is light, crisp, acidic, and clean through the finish. Overall, this is a wonderfully crafted and subtle beer. Very light and drinkable, yet complex.

4 ounce sample on tap at the Davis Beer Shoppe.  The aroma has a fair amount of banana esters and a distinct dustiness.  Fairly fruity.  Body is a moderately hazy golden color with a smallish, off-yellow head.  Starts spicy, dry, and quite carbonated.  Very bubbly--champagne-esque.  Becomes fruity with mild yeast dusty esters.  Strong carbonation throughout.  Fairly drinkable, but it would be more drinkable if the carbonation was toned down.  The carbonation hides the flavors and creates a bit of a one-dimensional beer.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2015 Have deleted my previous rating as it was just all wrong. I much prefer this beer this time. Changing palate, I guess. Aroma is great, lightly spicy, belgian yeastiness, tropical and citrus fruit. Taste is great too. Yoghurt, orange, slightly medicinal (in a good way), tropical fruit. Very nice.

Aroma is Poperingse hop and Belgian yeast, touch of swamp.
Flavour is mild hop with light malt. Highly drinkable, but nothing special.
UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 Draught at Craft Beer Co. Hazy golden, medium white head. Spicy, a bit cloyingly so. Semi dry low bitterness. Not my kind of wit.
Tap @ Craft Beer Co. Pours clear honey golden with a small white head. Aroma is hoppy, fruity and malty. Flavor is fruity, honey, citric and perry. Finishes fruity bitter.
Draught at Craft Beer, London. Pelg olden beer, small offwhite head. Spicy hoppy aroma, grapefruit and some floral notes. Floral perfume flavor, grapefruit, pepper, spicy notes. Floral spicy finish.

Hazy golden with a large white head.  Lightly spiced aroma, yeast, a bit of hops, and light fruits.  Sweet fruits, light spices, a bit of wheat, a bit of citrus, and floral.  Medium, carbonated body.  Pretty fun brew but not an everyday drinker.

750 ml bottle. Pours a cloudy orange hue with a medium thick white head. A great nose full of oranges, pepper, some banana, sage, very complex. The flavor is very nice; sweet light peppery and citrus flavors, lemons, dry, pears, full bodied and lingering sweet dry Belgian yeast. Very nice.

Bottle from summer secret santa 2011 (ragesaq). Pours cloudy pale golden color with big white head. Floral and perfumey hops and herbal aroma with doughy yeast. Light doughy flavor with lots of citrus and herbal notes. Very earthy and a little peppery. Light to medium body with lively carbonation. Thanks Aaron.
Had this one at the ACBF 2011. Golden colored brew. Spicy aroma. Flavor has spices, yeast, some hops, soapy. Ok.
At ACBF 2011.  Pale gold, coludy.  Saisony aroma.  Some lemon, touch of peachy soap.  Touch too soapy maybe.  Good dryness though.
Pretty cloudy golden pour. Beautiful herbal nose with great yeast and pepper components. Flavor holds awesome spice, yeast, and citrus. Awesome crisp palate. Wonderful saison.

Pours a fairly clear light golden color with big white, effervescent head with lacing that recedes quickly.  Aromas of spices, hay, and earthiness, some bananas.  Taste is mildly sweet with some light bitterness.  Palate is a little fizzy with a dry finish.  Overall, tasty brew that is true style.  Like the sage addition.
Bottle at Olympen. Hazy golden with a big head. Spicy fruit nose. Rich herbal and fruity flavours, quite complex. Hints of vegetables and oregano. A nice refresher.

I like the label, blair witch wanna be .. . Pours a dark gold tan, decent foam, really good lacing .. . good dose of yeast, earthy, and light over ripe fruit, peaches and pits .. . light to medium mouthfeel, could be cleaned up abit .. . i did enjoy it, but pulled me around abit .. . are the poatoes exploding yet??

A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a prodigious, four-finger thick, pale head that forms an interesting, varied head as it slowly subsides as well as leaving lots of lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is a hazy, honey-amber color that shows a deeply hazed, orange, straw color when held up to the light.  The aroma has an earthy back note of Dupont-yeast like spiciness and I think the sage comes in here as well.  Up front the beer has a citrus character as well as a fruity, almost tropical fruit character that perhaps reminds me a bit of juicy fruit bubblegum character; it is interesting that the hop fruit character really melds with the rustic spiciness and it transforms the hop character to be something completely different than one would find in a cleaner IPA.  Specific aromatic notes of Meyer Lemon, lychee, candied lime, woody sage, a musty woodiness, a touch of phenolics that isnt quite medicinal or plastic like.  I like the juicy hop character here, it really works with the hint of sage and rustic yeast aromatics.

The beer is quite dry tasting, and nicely light bodied; the body still has a touch of viscous character, just enough to keep this from being watery.  There is quite a bit of zippy carbonation, though it is not on the high side for a Saison.  The beer has quite a bit of up front hoppiness that has flavors of lychee, super ripe tangelo, Meyer Lemon, and Curacao orange zest.  This up front character is not quite dominant, there is a strong, woody sage note and a touch of bitterness in the finish, and a deep earthy spiciness and yeast phenolic character towards the finish.  The sage is actually perhaps the most dominant character in the flavor, but it couples quite prominently with a spicy, peppery fermentation character.  The finish really has a sharpness and bite to it, this seems to be a combination of the hop character, the sage and the fermentation character.  The hops and fermentation spiciness combine to form a sort of Japanese, pickled ginger character, as well as a spicy herbal character.  There is an earthy, yeast character here that seems to suggest that quite a bit of the haze in this beer is due to yeast (I really didnt give this any time to settle), but this is certainly not a bad thing and adds to the rusticity.

This is quite a nice Saison, it is certainly a bit rough around the edges, but that just adds to the character.  The balance towards rough is caused by the ample hop character that I am quite enjoying, so I definitely wouldnt want the hops to be reduced in order to make this softer / rounder.  This is definitely my type of Americanized Saison.
Nice carbonation. Interesting sweetness in the flavor, somewhat dry but not completely. Fruity, spicy (pepper), herbal (pine) in all large measure. OK, but not great. Looks lovely in the glass.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Sample from a bottle at PIB. Pours translucent yellow with a fine white lacing. Aroma of yeast, cider qualities, floral. Falour of yeast, coriander and floral tones. Nice flavours. Medium bodied. Complex.

Tap various times at Paradiso and Churchkey. A go to beer of mine nowadays though I am exciting to open a few bottles of this in the future to compare. The pour is a glowing, fully translucent/cloudy bright cobalt yellow with a modest, dense, eggshell head. Sticky lace. Nose is similar to Southampton Cuvee de Fleurs: rich tangerine sherbet, mango sorbet, muted chamomile and lavender. Taste is rich peach ice cream, tangelo, fresh honey dough and dried pineapple. Unreal palate: aerated and fluffy with insane softness. Very similar to Cuvee de Fleurs. Amazing.

bottle.  pours a cloudy gold with a very large foamy white head.  lemon, vanilla, sage aroma.  carbonation is very high in this one with a light body.  the flavors are mostly vanilla with doughy malt, white cake and a clean herbal(sage) finish.  the carbonation was too much for me.

Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  A hazy golden beer that has a nice big soapy off white head.  Thick lacing.  Herbal and soft fruit including apples in the nose.  That is also tasted along with pears and cinnamon.  Tasty!

Sampled from bottle at PIB, pours hazy / murky yellow with a small white head. Aroma of barnyard funk, sort of a pot-like quality, lemon zest and dry-like character. Flavour is very dry fruits, lemon zest, yeast, with a dry palate and a funky / yeasty finish. Wonderful saison.
Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, light citrus, light grape, herbal, sage. Flavour is malt, fruit, citrus and sage.

(Bottle) Pours hazy dark yellow with a white head. The aroma holds soft sweet citrus (tangerine, lemon and lime), coriander/spices, cracker-like malt, light phenols and incense. Undertones of wheat, wet grass, wet asphalt, clove, white pepper, salvia, mint, lavender, matchstick, earth (maybe barnyard), dust and flower shop. The nose is perfect in balance. A light touch of yellow fruit/pineapple and pear esters as the beer gets warmer. Super dirty in a rather clean way. The flavor is dusty dry, light bitter and light acidic. Tones of flowers, herbs, spices, citrus, subtle fruits, crackers, dust, wet stone and light incense smoke. The mouthfeel is clean, dusty and soft with a medium crisp carbonation. The finish holds numbing spices, dust, wheat, yeast, fancy hops, tangerines and crackers. Medium bodied. For me this beer is a perfect symbol of what is wrong with the ratebeer community - a fantastic beer without the epithet Imp o Barrel-whatever will never be an evergreen on the top 50 list (let him who is without sin cast the first stone). Anyhow, as the kids say: OMG! just as ass kicking as a good white whine.

Sampled at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011. Pours an unclear and pale yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is malt and spices. The flavor is malt, yeast, fruit and flowers. The palate is sweetness. Overall a good beer.

(750ml bottle from Total Wine Tempe).  Pour cloudy yellow-orange with a white head.  Aroma has sage, lemon and some wheat.  Taste is sweet  that follows the aroma. Tap at Beer Temple, Amsterdam: Golden coloured brew with an good hoppy and fruity taste.

Aroma: Acid, yeasts
Appearance: yellow, very cloudy
Taste: Acid, unexpected, bad
Palate: medium body
Overall: 10/20
Draught, KØ11. Cloudy yellow colour. Very small white head. OK lemon peel. Good refreshing, citric nice.

Draught at Københavnske Øldage 2011. 
Cloudy golden, small head. Fruity sage aroma. Sweet and fruity, above medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Some syrup and green apples. Low bitterness. Quite American in its approach.

Very bright yellow with a big pure white head.  To smell this beer is to 
smell a soapy yeast cake.  Hmmm.. Dawn Dish Soap and yeast mixed with some spices. It sounds like a bad thing, but it is a familiar and expected aroma with this type of beer.  Not off-putting at all.  Flavor is clean,
simple, and still remains interesting. Citrusy, yeasty, lemony.  Crisp, dry, finish which I really enjoy.  An awesome summer beer with amazing drinkability.

Keg at Craft Beer Co. It pours light straw yellow, with a very thick, foamy white head. The nose is ginger, zesty lemon, hay and white bread. The taste is hay, grass, lemon, grapefruit, fiery ginger, pepper, herbal, metal, white bread and butter, with a bitter-dry finish. A decent enough saison, but doesnt stand out from the crowd.

On tap at Poor Phils... Dark murky honey gold, a nice off white head, creamy, lasting... Floral hops, strong, a bit of soap, herbal lots of aloe or eucalyptus, dont like that... Much sweeter than I thought it would be, most of floral musk is gone, spicy aloe... Ok tasting but easy to drink

Bottle:   Cloudy straw, a little dark, on the orange side, large foamy head, nice lacing.   Nice bright floral nose, soft barnish and musty/basement notes.   This smells purdy good.   Floral on the tongue, a little mealy. &nbsp Also dusty.   Good, but wished it to be less mealy.   Moderate to full body and mouthfeel.   Dull, but strong, floral notes on the exit.   Also a bit of citrus zest, candied if you wil.   Pretty damn good stuff.

bottle-pours lite orange with a small soapy white head.  doesnt look like the stateside really.  noes of spicy hops, lite funky esters (brett, lemons, lite barnyard character), woody, organic (shovled earth).  flavors exhibit the spicy hops and the nice yeast twang going on-one of the best of this combination of yeast and hops.  again, spritzy body like stateside but it works here.  it adds to boosting the hop profile on the palate.  the earthy hops come out huge in the finish.  a very nice american twisted saison here that is full of flavors.  They need to bottle and distribute more Stillwater stuff.
Color is golden, little bit cloudy. Smell and taste not really good, think I tasted orange peel. Too much carbonation.

Bottle. Golden, cloudy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, malty  wheaty and sweetish aroma, some citrus fruitiness and lots of herbal spiciness. Body is medium, malty  wheaty and lightly sweetish flavor, some citrus and lots of herbal spiciness, yeast and some fruitiness. Finish is average, malty  wheaty and dryish, citrus and sharp spiciness. OK but too much sharp spiciness and wheat for me.

750 ml bottle.
Pours a dark, hazy orange colour with a large, frothy, white head. Aroma of strong citrus, spices and some earthy notes. Flavour of citrusy hops, sweet fruits such as apricot, spices and some floral notes. Medium bodied with a foamy mouthfeel and quite rough carbonation. Nice saison with too much carbonation.
bottled, thanks to wavers1 in trade, opaque orange with creamy white foam, aroma of pineapples and sage, flavors of pineapple, lemon, grainy wheat, pumpkin seed, nice saison

Golden with a nice white head. Intersting herbal nose, light to medium body, nice bitterness, the sage character is a little too intense for me but its not bad. Again, a little on the sweet side for a saison...
This poured a cloudy darker yellow color with a white head. Aroma was lots of yeast and spices, somewhat musty too. Flavor was very lightly tart, dry, and spicey, mainly lemon and coriander.
Bottle; cloudy golden with very large white head; aroma-grass, citrus, sage, earthy-very unusual but pleasant; taste-mild sweetness, moderate bitterness, sage coming through strongly again.

Pours a semi hazy gold with massive big white head.  Big sage nose, clean and citrusy.  Flavor is very similar.  Sweeter than I had thought it would be.  Very bubbly and champagne like.  Good for what it is, but I dont particularly care for it.

Bottle from Liquor Loft.  Murky yellow pour with white head and visible carbonation.  Nice buttery, wheat and sage spice aroma.  Light lemon and wheat taste with yeast, orange peel and perfume.  Not always a big saison fan - but this is an interesting little sipper.

Sampler at CBF 2011-05-27. Murky yellow with a white, creamy film. Spicy, cardamum, perfume aroma. Sweet, heavy bitter, acidic flavors with spicy notes. Prickling tongue. Full body. Grows in the mouth. Dry finish. Suspect bacterial infection from the acidic presence.

CPH BF 2011. Golden colour, small head. Aroma is sweet fruits, some mild soapy notes along with mild yeast, earth and herbs. Flavour is quite similar. Good attempt, but I felt this was a bit too clean and fruity to be really nice.
Unclear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, yeasty and light spicy - ginger. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 260511
Bottle shared by a generous person on RBSG bus. Pours lemon gold with white head. Nose/taste of lemon zest, yeast, coriander, spice, orange peel and herbs de provence.

Much thanks to whoever brought this to RBSG. Pours out a slightly cloudy golden/straw color with a thin white head. Aroma is of light spices, some nice earthy notes, and some light bitterness. Taste is complex with a well carbonated body, notes of light herbs, some pepper, earth, light fruity yeast and some lingering bitterness on the finish, which is rather dry. Very solid and easy drinking saison. Top notch.

(bottle from ksurkin, thanks Ken!)  Pours a very hazy straw-colored yellow with a large, foamy, white head that retains well.  Aroma is very musty, damp, and earthy, with brighter peaks of lemon zest rising above the must and dampness.  Some peppery and earthy sage as well along with an abundant floral note that I found rather appealing.  Could be some peppermint lurking underneath as it kicks up from time to time.  Very nice aroma here.  The flavor is simple, but executed flawlessly.  Flavor starts out with some base pale malt sweetness, but quickly escalates to a bready, earthy, and slightly spicy mid that is excellent.  Little spikes of citrus sting the tastebuds during the mid, further accentuating the positives of this stage of the beer.  The finish rounds out to be dry, crisp from the wheat, and lightly peppery as well.  Mouthfeel is soft from bottle conditioning and is medium bodied.  This beer just really hit on all cylinders and is absolutely perfect for the summer.  Thanks again Ken!
